div.p:
- I have written to Lord Rope and have desired
him to request Lord Oxmantown will commu-
nicate communicate his answer to you - May 1825

- I have also written to Leslie Foster desiring
him to do ditto - Both gentlemen ought I
think and will I hope be gratified & obliged
by your application - I told L F that if he did
not chuse to give his reasons publickly for not
liking your company they should not go far-
ther farther than to you if he trusts them to me - But
I think there must be some mistake about
his disapproval -
Bellamy's bible - I enclose a draft for ten gui-
neas guineas - most willingly Dear Francis to forward
any wish of yours and thank you for mak-
-ing making known to me your wish - But my name
I cannot put down to this subscription - I do
not approve of the thing as far as I know - & I
do not know enough to decide to I think with you that
the Quarterly Rev. Review
has been very intemperate &
shews a dogmatic unchristian spirit - and I
should be sorry that Mr. Bellamy were put down
by such unfair means - But as Dr. J. said no
man can be written down in England by any
one but himself - If Mr. Bellamy be right his
book will sell without a subscription - if wrong
it will never sell with it - As far as I have been
informed the first assertion in Mr. B's prospectus
viz "that no translation from the Original Hebrew
(bible) has been made since the 128h. year of Christ is false -

The Commissioners in the reign of K James com-
pared the then translation with the Hebrew rectifying
whatever they thought errors and retaining only the old
language where they thought it gave the correct sense -
- This is tantamount to a complete translation - & you
cannot call this consecrating error - They might err &
so may Mr. Bellamy at this day - But they took nothing
for granted as far as their judgement went - As to the addi
tional means in the present times of understanding Hebrew
in our days whence do they come? - the new means
of improving in Greek are from the variety of new
editions of classical books lexicons &c -

Mr. Bellamy touches most important points -
- & you will say is it not right to hear compare &
judge? - Yes if I could judge or compare after I
have heard - But I have no means of doing so - It
must be all between hebrew scholar & hebrew scholar
as far as human judgment goes - and assertion
against assertion - all former scholars it appears
are against Mr. Bellamy - & who are to be his judges
now? - Not I - that is all of which I am clear -

But setting aside all these considerations
even supposing that I were convinced that I had
a probability of Darwins important advantage from the
book I would not publish my name as a sub-
scriber subscriber - for this reason - It has been, ever since
we became authors, my father's declared princi
ple principle and mine not to take any part in any
religious controversy - not in any way to med-
dle meddle with the subject of religion - This was done with my
own will & from my own belief that it was
right during the many years when I wrote
with my father - No change has taken place
in my opinions - To make a change in my
practice, now that he is no more would be
most base - It would leave the false inference
open that I acted under influence and that
now that influence has ceased my conduct changes

- Supposing that my opinions had changed
I would not do this - No mortal has a right to
ask what they are - that is an affair between me
& my God - But no worldly motive could induce
me to bend to the side on which I see my world-
ly worldly interest & to which my conscience and
understanding do not justify me in bending

I need not say my dear friend that all this
is for you alone - Maria E May 1825
